Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF: The Silicification of Soft-Bodied Biotas: Reconstructing the Preservation, Ecology and Environments of Earth's Earliest Animal Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Lidya Tarhan has been awarded an NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a research and broadening participation plan, focused on the diversification of complex life, at Yale University and the California Institute of Technology. Through a multidisciplinary approach, employing novel geochemical, petrographic, paleobiological and experimental techniques, she will investigate the biogeochemical processes and particularly the role of early-stage silicification in the fossilization of Earth's earliest animal communities. Exceptionally preserved soft-bodied fossil assemblages offer unique windows into the biology, ecology and chemistry of ancient communities and environments. Developing models to explain the fossilization pathways responsible for this exceptional preservation is essential to reconstructing the initial steps in biological diversification, as well as the environmental conditions that prevailed during the radiation of early complex life. Further, many of the emerging analytical techniques Dr. Tarhan will utilize may help to shed light not only on the processes responsible for the exceptional preservation of fossils in sandstones, but also the role played by early- and late-stage cementation in the development of porosity and permeability in sandstone petroleum reservoirs. Her mentoring and outreach efforts will be carried out in association with the world-class collections and educational and outreach programs of Yale University's Peabody Museum. For instance, she will foster the development of scientific inquiry and critical thinking skills of student groups underrepresented in the sciences through participation in the Peabody's EVOLUTIONS after-school program, as well as by mentoring undergraduate geoscience research projects.

The Ediacara Biota, Earth's earliest animal ecosystem, is preserved in terminal Ediacaran (~580-541 million years old) strata worldwide. Ediacara fossil assemblages consist of exceptionally preserved soft-bodied forms of enigmatic morphology and affinity. The majority of Ediacara fossil assemblages are preserved in situ as casts and molds in sandstone beds. However, there is little mechanistic understanding of how the soft-bodied Ediacara Biota and similar sandstone-hosted younger biotas were preserved, hindering attempts to reconstruct the biology and ecology of these seminal communities. Our knowledge of the ecology of these organisms-information that is essential to analyzing the transition from the Ediacara Biota to the faunas of the Phanerozoic (our current eon of Earth history) and to resolve the ecological and biogeochemical character of the Ediacaran-Phanerozoic transition-is currently incomplete. A full understanding of the fossilization pathways unique to this interval in Earth history is essential to reconstruct the complexity of these early animal ecosystems. This work will shed light on long-standing issues in Ediacaran and early Phanerozoic paleobiology, and also illuminate the role played by environment in the early development, radiation and preservation of complex life on Earth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellow Dr. Lidya Tarhan has been working on unraveling the environmental and ecological factors responsible for the diversification of complex life and its preservation in the fossil record. Using a multidisciplinary approach, employing novel geochemical, petrographic, paleobiological and experimental techniques, she investigated the biogeochemical processes responsible for the fossilization of Earth’s earliest complex seafloor communities—the Ediacara Biota. The Ediacara Biota is preserved in terminal Ediacaran (571–541 million-year-old) geologic strata worldwide. Ediacara fossil assemblages consist of exceptionally preserved soft-bodied forms of enigmatic morphology and affinity. The majority of Ediacara fossil assemblages are preserved in situ as three-dimensional impressions (casts and molds) along sandstone bedding planes. However, there has previously been limited mechanistic understanding of how the soft-bodied Ediacara Biota and similar sandstone-hosted biotas were preserved, hampering attempts to reconstruct the biology and ecology of these seminal communities.

 

Dr. Tarhan analyzed fossils from the Ediacara Member of Australia—the ‘type deposit’ of the Ediacara Biota. She determined that fossilization of these seafloor communities as sandstone casts and molds was, shortly following their catastrophic burial and death, directly mediated by the precipitation of silica cements. Although the concentration of dissolved silica in the modern oceans is extremely low (due to biological drawdown by organisms—such as diatoms, radiolarians and silicifying sponges—that form siliceous tests and skeletal elements), prior to the radiation of silica-biomineralizers, the oceans would have been rich in dissolved silica, facilitating the precipitation of seafloor silica cements. Dr. Tarhan further determined that fossilization of soft-bodied organisms as sandstone casts and molds via silica cementation occurred across a wide range of shallow marine environments, and recorded a broad assortment of unrelated taxa. Moreover, this style of fossilization is not confined to the Ediacara Biota, but in fact characterizes a number of older and younger fossil deposits—including animal-dominated biotas of the Phanerozoic (our current eon of Earth history). That this preservational window persisted across the Ediacaran-Phanerozoic transition suggests that the disappearance of the Ediacara Biota at the end of the Ediacaran Period was not, as has commonly been suggested, a preservational artefact reflecting loss of the environmental conditions necessary for fossilization of these organisms, but rather a major extinction event and thus a meaningful evolutionarily signal.

 

A better understanding of the fossilization pathways responsible for exceptional fossil assemblages like the Ediacara Biota is essential to reconstruct the complexity of these early ecosystems and to determine their relationship to the diverse animal faunas that appear in the fossil record shortly thereafter. This work will help to resolve long-standing issues in Ediacaran and early Phanerozoic paleobiology and paleoecology, and illuminate the role played by environmental conditions in the early development, radiation and preservation of complex life on Earth. This research project also provided Dr. Tarhan with the opportunity to engage in a number of educational, mentoring and outreach efforts, including enrichment of classroom-, laboratory- and field-based student learning experiences, supervision of undergraduate student research projects and interaction with visitors to Yale University’s Peabody Museum of Natural History. Additionally, the emerging analytical techniques Dr. Tarhan employed for this project may prove equally applicable to other geoscience questions, and help to shed light on not only the processes responsible for exceptional preservation of fossils in sandstones, but also the role played by early- and late-stage cementation in the development of porosity and permeability in sandstone-hosted petroleum and groundwater reservoirs.
